title.narrative: Enhancing food regulatory systems and food safety in Suriname

description.narrative:
Suriname is well-endowed with natural resources, and its broadly open economy is largely dependent on the extractive industries, particularly gold and oil (and previously bauxite). The agricultural sector accounted for a relatively small 9% share of GDP in 2013, though it remains important because of its contribution to employment and foreign exchange generation. Most agricultural production takes place along the coastal plains.
As part of its development strategy, the Government of Suriname (GOS) has prioritized interventions to contribute to a more productive and diversified agricultural sector that will contribute to improve food security, and provide opportunities for employment and income generation.
The GOS has requested UNIDO’s support in interventions related to food regulatory enhancements and investments in upgrading the food/agri-food sector.
UNIDO’s intervention is designed to 1. help the Food Safety Agency (SNIV) achieve its vision and fulfill its entire food regulatory mandate. It was designed to lay down the foundations for a robust, transparent and internationally bench-marked food regulatory program. 2. Promote value-addition, innovation and export potential of the food / agri-food production Sector
